description: Demolition of part existing dwelling and erection of 3 storey building to provide 3 no. self-contained residential units/flats (2 x two-bedroom and 1 x three bedroom) with associated amenity space, parking for 3 cars, and storage for waste/recycling and cycles
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

The site and building works required to implement the development shall be only carried out between the hours of 08.00 and 18.00 Mondays to Fridays and between 08.00 and 13.00 on Saturdays and not at all on Bank Holidays and Sundays.Reason:  To safeguard the amenities of the adjoining residential occupiers in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the commencement of the development a Construction Method Statement shall be submitted to and agreed by the Local Planning Authority outlining measures that will be taken to control dust, noise and other environmental impacts of the development.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to protect local air quality and safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers, in compliance with h Policy 7.14 of the London Plan and the GLA SPG Control of Dust and Emissions during Construction  and Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to implementation of the relevant part of the development, a scheme of noise insulation/reduction shall be submitted to ensure that the noise level of 35 dBLAeq,16 hour  in living rooms and bedrooms during the daytime (0700 to 2300 hours) and 30 dBLAeq,8 hour  and 45 dBLAmax during the night time (measured with F time-weighting and between 2300 and 0700 hours) in bedrooms in accordance with BS8233:2014 shall not be exceeded.  Where these levels cannot be met with windows open appropriate acoustic ventilation should be provided so that the room can be sufficiently ventilated.  The acoustic performance of any passive vent, variable speed mechanical air supply unit or whole house ventilation must be sufficient to ensure that the noise level standards given above are not compromised.The development shall be built and maintained in accordance with the agreed details.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of future residential occupiers in accordance with Policy DM10 of the of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The car parking accommodation shown upon the approved drawings shall be provided with a hard bound dust free surface, adequately drained before the development to which it relates is occupied and thereafter it shall be kept free from obstruction at all times for use by the occupier of the development and shall not thereafter be used for any purpose other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of the development and visitors to it. The parking accommodation shall provide a minimum of one active electric charging space ECV, and the remaining spaces shall be reserved as passive ECV or for active charging, to be maintained for the lifetime of the development.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking accommodation and to avoid the congestion of surrounding roads by parked vehicles in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The car parking identified upon the approved drawings shall be reserved for car parking by occupiers of the dwellings hereby permitted and their visitors and for no other purpose, and shall provide a minimum of one active electric charging space ECV, and the remaining spaces shall be reserved as passive ECV, to be maintained for the lifetime of the development.Reason: In order to reserve car parking spaces for the use of residents in accordance with Policies DM9 (Managing Vehicle Use for New Development) and Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The hard surface hereby approved shall be made of porous materials and retained thereafter or provision shall be made and retained thereafter to direct run-off water from the hard surface to a permeable or porous area or surface within the curtilage of the property.Reason: To reduce the risk of flooding and pollution and increase the level of sustainability of the development and to comply with Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No building or use hereby permitted shall be occupied or the use commenced until the cycle parking provision shown on the approved plans has been completed, and thereafter, be kept free of obstructions and available for the parking of cycles only.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate cycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No development shall take place including any works of demolition until a construction logistics plan has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority in consultation with Transport for London.  The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for works traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Measures to protect any tree, shrubbery and other landscape features to be retained on the site during the course of development.(h) Means of enclosure of the site.(i) Wheel washing equipment.(j) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(k) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

A sample of the facing materials to be utilised in the development hereby permitted shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before any works above ground are commenced. The development shall then be built in accordance with these approved samples, and permanently retained thereafter.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012. These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset.

Detailed drawings or specifications of the following shall be submitted to and be approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before the relevant part of work is begun. The  detail  thereby  approved  shall  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  that approval in accordance with Policies DM10. (i) boundary treatment(ii) window and door openings (including cross sections)(iii) louvred screen(iv) elevations of refuse and recycling enclosure(v) elevations of cycle storeReason:  In the interests of visual amenity and the character of the area. These details are required prior to commencement of development to ensure the development would have a satisfactory appearance.

During the period between the commencement and the substantial completion of the development approved by this permission, any trees on the site which are shown as being retained on the relevant approved plans shall be protected by way of fencing which meets the requirements of BS5837: 2005 "Protection of Trees on Construction Sites" (figures 4 and 5). The fenced area(s) shall be kept entirely free at all times of vehicles, vehicle movements, equipment and machinery. There shall be no changes to the soil level and no excavation of trenches within the fenced areas, no fires lit, no dumping of toxic chemicals and no retained trees shall be used for winching purposes.  If any retained tree is removed, uprooted, destroyed, dies, or is pruned or damaged in a way which negatively effects the amenity or landscape value of the tree, a replacement tree shall be planted in the same location, the size and species of which may be specified in writing by the council.Reason: To prevent unnecessary damage occurring to the trees during building operations, thereby safeguarding the visual amenities of the site in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to any above ground level works a detailed hard and soft landscaping scheme including detailed planting plan with species, sizes, numbers and densities, shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following completion of the development and the tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority.  Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.  Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Evidence must be submitted to the Council confirming that the development hereby permitted has achieved no less than the C02 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes Level 4.  Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of Evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from ENE1 and WAT1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Guide.  Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 Part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105L/day.Reason: In the interests of Sustainability and Energy Conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (July 2011) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby approved shall not commence until a Sustainable Drainage Strategy and associated detailed design, management and maintenance plan of surface water drainage for the site using Suds methods has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved drainage system shall be implemented in accordance with the approved Sustainable Drainage Strategy prior to the use of the building commencing and maintained thereafter for the lifetime of the development.Reason: To prevent the increased risk of flooding by ensuring the provision of a satisfactory means of surface water disposal is incorporated into the design and the build and that the principles of sustainable drainage are incorporated into this proposal and maintained for the lifetime of the proposal, in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (July 2011) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No flues or pipework shall be fixed to the elevations other than those shown on the drawings hereby approved or in accordance with details which shall have first been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: In the interests of the visual amenities of the area in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No fans, louvres, ducts, external lighting or other external plant other than those shown on the drawings hereby approved shall be installed without the prior written approval of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the occupiers of the neighbouring properties and the visual amenities of the area in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No unit hereby permitted shall be occupied until the refuse store and area/facilities allocated for storing of recyclable materials, as shown on the approved drawings have been completed in accordance with the approved plans. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development shall either be stored within this dedicated store/area as shown on the approved plans, or internally within the building(s) that form part of the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material shall be stored or placed for collection on the public highway or pavement, except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure the provision of refuse facilities to the satisfaction of the Council in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

All units within the apartment building hereby approved shall be built to meet Building Regulation requirement M4(2) 'accessible and adaptable dwellings'.Reason: To ensure compliance with  Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012, and Policies 3.5 and Policy 3.8 of the London Plan 2016.
A1 - Loading

The assessment of this application has been based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings. If you carry out development based on incorrect plans you may be liable to the Council taking enforcement action against you

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above, are agreed and that Condition 5 (Landscaping Scheme) of Planning Permission 17/14038/FUL, is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above, are agreed and that Condition 7 (Arboricultural Method Statement) of Planning Permission 17/14038/FUL, is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.11 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed single storey side replacement extension is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. The proposed hip-to-gable extension roof extension would not strictly adhere to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, given that it would unbalance the roofs of the semi-detached properties, however given that a a number of similar extensions are viewed within the Rowlls Road streetscene, officers consider it would not detract from the character and appearance of the original dwelling and surrounding area.The proposed rear dormer roof extensions would not strictly adhere to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, given that it would not be appropriately set down from the ridge of the original roofslope, or in from the eaves or sides of the roofslope, however given that a a number of similar extensions are viewed within the Rowlls Road streetscene, officers consider it would not detract from the character and appearance of the original dwelling and surrounding area.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the siting of the proposed extensions in relation to the neighbouring properties, and that no windows are proposed to the side elevation, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above, are agreed and that Condition 8 (Means of Enclosure) of Planning Permission 17/14038/FUL, is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above, are agreed and that Condition 11 (Design of Internal Driveway) of Planning Permission 17/14038/FUL, is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above, are agreed and that Condition 18 (Surface Water Drainage Strategy) of Planning Permission 17/14038/FUL, is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above, are agreed and that Condition 20 (Waste Water) of Planning Permission 17/14038/FUL, is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.
The applicant is advised that Condition 21 (Levels) of Planning Permission 17/14038/FUL is a controlling condition and does not need to formally be submitted for approval.

SiteThe application site is a two-storey semi-detached dwelling house located on the southern side of Croylands Drive. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Consultations7 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 1 representation has been received objecting to the proposal on the following grounds:Noise, dirt and pollution created by the proposed development.The above issues would be limited to the construction phase and managed through building regulations and other legislation to minimise impacts beyond the application property. ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance; and, The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The proposed extension would replace an existing conservatory with a single storey rear extension, with a stepped appearance projecting further on one side than the other. The pitched roof extension would be of an appropriate scale, with external materials to match the existing property. The extension would align with the neighbouring rear extension at No.13 Croylands Drive and maintain the existing setback to No.11.  It would not be visible from the street and would therefore have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the wider area.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: The principal properties to consider are Nos.11 and 13 Croylands Drive. The neighbouring property at No. 13 Croylands Drive has been extended to the rear and the proposed rear extension would match the building line of this property. To No.11 Croylands Drive the proposal would maintain its existing setback from the shared boundary, and given the modest projection of the extension at this point. Officers therefore consider that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of any neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above, are agreed and that Condition 3 (Materials) of planning permission 19/00125/FUL, is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling located within the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character (a non designated heritage asset).ProposalErection of a single storey front porch, side and rear extension.Officers note that planning permission was previously granted (19/02765/HOU dated 10/01/2020) for the erection of a a single storey side/rear extension with associated works which is already under construction. This application would be for a similar development with the addition of a porch to the front of the property.ConsultationSeven neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Officers note that the property currently has a small flat roofed porch. Therefore, the proposed extensions and alterations to the front of the property would not be completely dissimilar to the existing situation. In combination the proposed extensions to the front, side and rear would not be of an insignificant scale, however, they would be in keeping with the host dwelling and would result in no harm the character or appearance of the area.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.HeritageParagraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.As stated above the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character is a non-designated heritage asset.  Paragraph 203 of the NPPF states that:The effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining the application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement will be required having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.Officer comment: As set out above, it is considered that there would be no adverse impact in terms of character and appearance as a result of the proposals.  Therefore, it follows that Officers consider that there would be no harm to the significance of the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above, are agreed and that the Planning Condition 7 of planning permission 19/01750/FUL is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details for Condition 7 (CO2 Reductions/Internal Water Useage) of Planning Permission ref: 18/014637/FUL has been assessed and is hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details.

The proposed extensions and alterations are considered to fall within the parameters of  permitted development as set out under Schedule 2, Part 1, Classes A, B & C  of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).

The assessment of this application has been based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If you carry out development based on incorrect plans you may be liable to the Council taking enforcement action against you.

SiteThe application site is a two-storey end of terrace dwellinghouse located on Tolworth Road. The site is located within Flood Zone 2 (medium probability).ProposalThe proposal would involve the demolition of existing garage, erection of two storey side and rear timber canopy extension. Alteration to existing rear extension including installation of 1 no rooflight. Installation of pv panels in rear roof.Relevant History21/03037/HOU - Demolition of existing garage and erection of two-storey side extension. Alterations to existing rear extension including changes to fenestration and installation of 1no rooflight. Installation of PV panels to rear roof. Erection of rear timber canopy. This previous application was refused for the following reason:By reason of its siting, mass and height the side extension would appear disproportionate to the original dwelling and would appear excessive in scale and dominant within the immediate streetscene. In addition, the proposed extension would not be set in from the boundary and could therefore lead to a terracing effect between properties. The proposal would have an unacceptable impact upon the character and appearance of the dwellinghouse and the streetscene, thereby conflicting with Policies D3 of the London Plan 2021, Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and Policy Guidance 36 of the Residential Design SPD, 2013.Consultations11 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance; The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings;The impact of the development on highways; and,The impact of the development on flood risk. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: Officers note that the proposed two storey side extension would not be set back from the front elevation, or set down from the ridgeline of the roof by 500mm as recommended by the Residential Design SPD 2013. Nor would it be set in sufficiently from the boundary in accordance with the Council's guidance. Officers note that the proposed extension would be set in marginally from the boundary by approximately 0.3 metres and acknowledge that there is an access path between the property at No. 117 Tolworth Road and its neighbour and No. 115 Tolworth Road. Due to this slight set in, in conjunction with the site's proximity to the access path, the proposed extensions are unlikely to lead to a terracing effect. However, officers consider that the proposed two storey side extension would appear disproportionate to the original dwelling and would appear excessive in scale and dominant within the immediate streetscene. As such, Officers consider that the previous reason for refusal in relation to application 21/03037/HOU has not been adequately addressed.The other aspects of the proposal are considered acceptable in character and appearance terms.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Policy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy T5 of the London Plan 2021 states that developments should provide cycle parking at least in accordance with the minimum standards set out in Table 10.2 and Figure 10.3.Policy DM9 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy (2012) states that new development must comply with local car parking standards in order that it does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety. Policy DM10 supports this stance. Officers Comments: The proposal involves the removal of an existing garage. Despite this loss, it is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling remains of an adequate size to accommodate at least two off-street car parking spaces. Whilst this level of provision would be in excess of the maximum standards set out in the London Plan, this issue would not warrant a reason for refusal as it is reflective of the existing situation.In terms of cycle parking Officers note that due to the loss of the garage and the side access to the rear of the property, it is unclear as to how secure cycle parking storage would be accommodated on site in accordance with the standards set out in the London Plan. In the event of an approval it is considered appropriate to require these details via condition to ensure compliance.Policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.Officers Comments: The site is located within Flood Zone 2, which has a medium probability of flooding. The submitted flood risk assessment states that floor levels within the proposed development would be set no lower than existing floor levels and flood proofing of the proposed development has been incorporated where appropriate. This is considered acceptable in this case and in compliance with Policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).In conclusion and overall the proposed development would conflict with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).
Please provide scale bars on existing and proposed drawings

Please provide existing and proposed floor plans at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing the outline of entire floor plan, not just part and all key dimensions for the proposed works. The plans must also show the direction of North. Although the inclusion of a scale bar is not mandatory, it is encouraged.The submitted floor plans do not have a North point.

Please provide existing and proposed roof plans at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing the outline of entire property not just part and showing dimensions of proposed work. The plans must show the direction of North. Although the inclusion of a scale bar is not mandatory, it is highly encouraged.The submitted roof plans do not have a North point
Please provide a payment of £206 to accompany your application. This payment can be made online at www.kingston.gov.uk or by calling our Customer Care Line on 020 8547 5022

Please be advised that the proposed description on your submitted application form, does not refer to the front porch extension. In the avoidance of dount, kindly confirm the following description meets the proposals of your application;''Erection of two storey side extension, single storey rear extension and front porch extension (following demolition of existing garage/store)''

The proposal include the formation of a drop kerb, for the avoidance of the doubt please confirm the ''access'' is reserved for later consideration or not.If the access is not reserved, please revise the location plan to show the red outline in the proposed site including the front pavement, where the drop kerb will be proposed.Please submit a copy of an Ordnance Survey based site location plan scaled 1:1250 with the application site outlined in red and adjoining land owned by applicant in blue, showing at least two road frontages and a North point.

The description of this proposal is ''Erection of 3 storey building housing 9nos 3bed flats and 2 storey building for separate nursery'', whereas the submitted new proposed  floor plans do not show the plan of the nursery block. Please revise the proposed floor plans and roof plan to show the plans of both buildings.Please provide proposed floor plans and roof plan at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing the outline of entire floor plan, not just part and all key dimensions for the proposed works. The plans must also show the direction of North. Although the inclusion of a scale bar is not mandatory, it is encouraged.
